awd_titl_txt: Society for American Archaeology Native American Scholarships Program
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the inception of archaeology in the Americas, Native Americans have been the preferred subjects of scientific inquiry, classification, and interpretation, as their cultures, items of cultural patrimony, and ways of life were documented for perpetuity. Yet, Native Americans have been and continue to be dramatically underrepresented in the field of archaeology. The Society for American Archaeology recognizes the benefits of Native American and Indigenous participation in archaeology and has, for the past two decades, developed a Native American Scholarship Fund that supports training Native American and Indigenous archaeologists. These scholarships help ensure that indigenous knowledge and voices continue to become a more vibrant part of the fabric of understanding American culture and past human experience. 

The lasting impact of these scholarships has already impacted archaeology and the larger historic preservation community. For example, many of the past recipients of the SAA's Native American Scholarships indicate that their award enabled them to pursue careers in archaeology and in several cases inspired them to create similar opportunities for future generations of indigenous archaeologists to follow in their footsteps. Scholarships awarded through this grant support both graduate and undergraduate education and training in archaeology for Native American, Alaskan Native, and Native Hawaiian students and community members and recipients are selected through a competitive, criteria-based process. The funding provided by the National Science Foundation will enable the SAA to continue their legacy of supporting underrepresented communities within the field of archaeology as part of their commitment to the "Statement on Diversity," which makes inclusiveness an institutional and disciplinary goal. The SAA Native American Scholarship program is among the most visible and tangible mechanisms to show that archaeologists are invested in a future for their discipline that is fully inclusive to Native peoples.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Society of American Archaeology utilized NSF grants from 2019 to 2024 to support the training of fifteen (15) Native American, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian students in archaeology. This grant enables Indigenous students or employees of a tribal cultural preservation program to attend a field school or museum curation course, obtain training in analytical techniques, or undertake field or lab research. Or engage in other archaeological and heritage management training and research opportunities that are needed by their home communities. There are three additional scholarships that are awarded each year as part of the grant. These scholarships have created a pathway for highly skilled underrepresented students into the discipline, able to contribute and participate in archaeology, and create pathways for future generations of archaeologists from their home communities. These scholarships offer Native American, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian students opportunities to advance their skills and continue their education, while also being able to work in their home communities and homelands. 

Historically, there have been and there are very few Native Americans engaged in archaeology, which has created a narrow perspective of the past and the way that material culture is understood.  As a way to change this trend, the intent of the proposal is to support the training and skills that are necessary to engage in archaeology and heritage management activities, thereby creating space for other perspectives and understandings of the past, which also engages other disciplines and peoples in discovering and learning about our shared pasts. The overall impact of the project – awarding archaeological training scholarships to Native American students/ CRM practitioners – contributes to the disciplines of archaeology, museum studies, CRM, and other closely related fields on many levels, ranging from a practical level, the entry of more Native Americans into these disciplines, especially archaeology, within an epistemological level opens archaeological theory to include Native American and Indigenous knowledges. The archaeological training scholarships provide Native American students and community representatives with the opportunity to receive training and education that will make its way back into Native American Communities, tribal departments, and hopefully into the work of the tribal government. The variety and range of training sought after and completed through these scholarship applications have equipped these underrepresented groups with the knowledge to conduct archaeological and heritage management activities that are inclusive and supportive of Native American lifeways, epistemologies, ontologies, axiologies, and pedagogies. In turn, these developments within archaeology have supported the work of Indigenous archaeologies and archaeologists engaged with work with and by Native American and Indigenous Peoples. 

The increase in Native Americans and Indigenous Peoples into anthropology and other fields has profoundly changed the type and nature of research with Indigenous Peoples, but it has also changed the ethical engagement of researchers with Indigenous Peoples. Within the institutions that we are all a part of, we are seeing the impact of Indigenous knowledges and practitioners in enhancing our collective knowledge and understanding of our respective fields, but also the impacts that our work has on the communities that we are a part of. This kind of engagement has opened new avenues of research and new collaborative opportunities between Indigenous communities and researchers, as well as providing training to future generations of archaeologists and anthropologists, leading to a change in the practice of these disciplines while also creating sustainable pathways forward.
